channel.title: Stories from propublica.org - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best propublica.org stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Ventilators Aren't Going To Cure COVID-19. Here's What They Can Do
item.description: Since the beginning of the coronavirus outbreak, ventilators have been a key focus of the media, politicians and the president. But most of these references miss some key points.

item.title: Millions of Americans Might Not Get Stimulus Checks. Some Might Be Tricked Into Paying TurboTax to Get Theirs
item.description: Congress gave the IRS the job of sending out coronavirus rescue checks. But the underfunded agency is struggling, while for-profit companies like Intuit...

item.title: Climate Change Won't Stop For The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The next several months could bring hurricanes, floods and fire, on top of the pandemic currently raging through the country. How do you shelter in place during an evacuation?

item.title: How Panic Buying Has Put An Incredible Strain On Food Banks Even As The Need For Them Explodes
item.description: Panic shopping and hoarding have led to supply shortages. Volunteers frightened of the virus have stopped showing up. And a newly jobless population has sent demand soaring.

item.title: A Company Promised Cheap Ventilators To The Government, Never Delivered And Is Now Charging Quadruple The Price For New Ones
item.description: Royal Philips N.V. agreed in September to sell 10,000 ventilators to the US for $3,280 each. It did not deliver. But the Dutch company just announced a new deal with the government. This time, it's charging roughly $15,000 each.

item.title: We Still Don't Know How Many People Are In The Hospital With COVID-19
item.description: Many states report coronavirus cases and hospitalizations differently, and the federal government is behind on data tracking. Without consistent information, the US won't be able to respond as new COVID-19 hot spots emerge.

item.title: A Nurse Bought Protective Supplies For Her Colleagues Using GoFundMe. The Hospital Suspended Her
item.description: How a confrontation in one of the nation's Coronavirus hotspots illustrates a troubling national trend.

item.title: The Hate Store: Amazon's Self-Publishing Arm Is a Haven for White Supremacists
item.description: The company gives extremists and neo-Nazis banned from other platforms unprecedented access to a mainstream audience — and even promotes their books.

item.title: Cancer Surgeries And Organ Transplants Are Being Put Off For Coronavirus. Can They Wait?
item.description: In a given month, more than a million people have some kind of surgery. The elective procedures being postponed because of coronavirus aren't all optional. Cancer patients and organ recipients are being forced to wait.

item.title: Early Data Shows African Americans Have Contracted And Died Of Coronavirus At An Alarming Rate
item.description: No, the coronavirus is not an "equalizer." Black people are being infected and dying at higher rates. Here's what Milwaukee is doing about it — and why governments need to start releasing data on the race of COVID-19 patients.

item.title: Taxpayers Paid Millions To Design A Low-Cost Ventilator For A Pandemic. Instead, The Company Is Selling Versions Of It Overseas
item.description: As coronavirus sweeps the globe, there is not a single Trilogy Evo Universal ventilator in the US stockpile.

item.title: Here's Why Florida Got All The Emergency Medical Supplies It Requested While Other States Did Not
item.description: The Department of Health and Human Services has come under fire as several states' requests for supplies from the emergency medical stockpile go unfulfilled.

item.title: What We Know — And Don't Know — About Possible Coronavirus Treatments Promoted By Trump
item.description: There isn't enough evidence that decades-old anti-malarial drugs work for the treatment or prevention of coronavirus, but here's what we do know so far.

item.title: Internal Emails Show How Chaos At The CDC Slowed The Early Response To Coronavirus
item.description: The CDC fumbled its communication with public health officials and underestimated the threat of the coronavirus even as it gained a foothold in the United States, according to hundreds of pages of documents ProPublica obtained.

item.title: 'Our Goal Should Be To Crush The Curve'
item.description: A doctor-scholar who studied the 1976 mishandling of swine flu says the president is wrongly choosing between saving lives and saving the economy.

item.title: Walmart Was Almost Charged Criminally Over Opioids. Trump Appointees Killed The Indictment
item.description: Even as company pharmacists protested, Walmart kept filling suspicious prescriptions, stoking the country's opioid epidemic. Trump's people condoned it.

item.title: Lupus Patients Can't Get Crucial Medication After President Trump Pushes Unproven Coronavirus Treatment
item.description: Trump's unproven claim that hydroxychloroquine could be used to treat COVID-19 has led to hoarding, putting Lupus patients and others at even greater risk. As of Saturday afternoon, Anna Valdez had 27 pills left. That number is now down to 25.

item.title: Domestic Violence And Child Abuse Will Rise During Quarantines. So Will Neglect Of At-Risk People, Social Workers Say
item.description: Patchwork social service departments are scrambling to address the fallout of coronavirus restrictions, and social workers say vast numbers of at-risk, elderly, sick and disabled Americans will be imperiled. "We are going to see some deaths."

item.title: A Medical Worker Describes Terrifying Lung Failure From COVID-19 — Even In His Young Patients
item.description: "It first struck me how different it was when I saw my first coronavirus patient go bad. I was like, Holy shit, this is not the flu. Watching this relatively young guy, gasping for air, pink frothy secretions coming out of his tube."
item.kicker: 'LIKE THEY'VE BEEN HIT BY A TRUCK'

item.title: Senator Dumped Up To $1.6 Million Of Stock After Reassuring Public About Coronavirus Preparedness
item.description: Intelligence Chair Richard Burr's selloff came around the time he was receiving daily briefings on the health threat.

item.title: The Trump Administration Drove Him Back to China, Where He Invented a Fast Coronavirus Test
item.description: A federal crackdown on professors' undisclosed outside activities is achieving what China has long struggled to do: spur Chinese scientists to return home. In this crisis, it's costing the U.S. intellectual firepower.

item.title: Coronavirus Panic Buying Puts Grocery Workers And Shoppers At Risk Of Infection
item.description: Braving grocery store crowds when you're already stocked up puts you at risk of getting sick or infecting others, including elderly workers and others who have no choice but to be there.

item.title: This Coronavirus Is Unlike Anything In Our Lifetime, And We Have To Stop Comparing It To The Flu
item.description: Longtime health reporter Charles Ornstein says that comparing the novel coronavirus to the flu is dangerously inaccurate. Not one public health expert he trusts has called that comparison valid. Here's why.

item.title: Trump's Company Paid Bribes To Reduce Property Taxes, Assessors Say
item.description: Five former city employees and a former Trump Organization employee say the company used middlemen to pay New York City tax assessors to lower building assessments and pay less taxes in the 1980s and 1990s.

item.title: He Sexually Assaulted Her After They Met On Bumble. Then She Saw Him On Tinder. Then Hinge
item.description: Dating apps and the companies that own them talk a lot about caring about users' safety. But when the users we talked to reported their attackers on platforms, they often heard nothing in return. And their attackers profiles stayed active.

item.title: Dozens of Catholic Priests Credibly Accused Of Abuse Found Work Abroad, Some With The Church's Blessing
item.description: The Catholic Church allowed more than 50 US-based clergy to move abroad after facing credible accusations of sexual abuse. Some continued to work with children.

item.title: Beginner's Luck: How A Video Gambling Company Worked The Odds And Took Over A State
item.description: Funded in part by his wealthy family and aided by a personal connection at the Illinois Gaming Board, Andrew Rubenstein's Accel Entertainment now owns a third of the state's video gambling machines, making it the biggest video gambling operator in the nation.

item.title: When The Billionaire Family Behind The Opioid Crisis Needed PR Help, They Turned To Mike Bloomberg
item.description: Bloomberg gave media advice to the Sacklers and recommended his longtime mayoral spokesman to them. The relationship could shadow his presidential bid.

item.title: The FBI Is Investigating Massive Embezzlement Of Border Patrol Union Funds
item.description: The head of the powerful union representing border patrol agents nationwide said the FBI is working to identify who stole some $500,000 out of the coffers of the El Paso local. The theft raises more questions about lawlessness in the union's ranks.

item.title: TurboTax Is Still Tricking Customers With Tax Prep Ads That Misuse The Word 'Free'
item.description: Intuit has amped up its misleading digital advertising in the wake of a new IRS agreement that bars tax prep companies from burying the agency's Free File program.

item.title: Warship Accidents Left Sailors Traumatized. The Navy Struggled To Treat Them
item.description: Recent wars have forced the US military to acknowledge and treat the psychological wounds caused by trauma. But some sailors who survived 2017's deadly crashes say the Navy's efforts to help them sometimes fell short.

item.title: How The Maker Of The 'Big Kid' Booster Seat Put Profits Over Child Safety
item.description: Internal video of side-impact tests shows that children could be injured or killed in Evenflo's "Big Kid" booster seats. But the company continued to market them as "side-impact tested."

item.title: How The Border Patrol's New Powers And Old Carelessness Separated A Family
item.description: Under Trump, Border Patrol agents wield nearly unchecked power over the fate of migrants — and their seemingly random decisions can cleave families apart.
item.kicker: 'WOMEN TO ONE SIDE, MEN TO THE OTHER'

item.title: An E-Cigarette Grey Market Lets Kentucky Prison Officials Rake In Money
item.description: In May, 2017, Kentucky banned the use of e-cigarettes and vapes in state buildings and certain public places. It hurt prison officials the most — because it was an easy and highly inflated source of revenue. Soon enough, a grey market was established and the cash started to flow back in.

item.title: How These Jail Officials Profit From Selling E-Cigarettes To Inmates
item.description: Many cash-strapped Kentucky jails prop up their budgets by selling e-cigarettes to inmates, making more than $1.3 million in 2018. Some jailers, or their friends and family, are making money while jails overlook the health concerns of vaping products.

item.title: Catholic Leaders Promised Transparency About Child Abuse. They Haven't Delivered
item.description: After decades of shielding accused child abusers from the public, many Catholic leaders are now releasing lists of their names. But the lists are inconsistent, incomplete and omit key details.

item.title: Who's Afraid Of The IRS? Not Facebook
item.description: The company is about to face off with the tax agency in a rare trial to capture billions that the IRS thinks Facebook owes. But onerous budget cuts have hamstrung the agency's ability to bring the case.

item.title: Operation Encore And The Saudi Connection: A Secret History Of The 9/11 Investigation
item.description: Behind the scenes, a team of FBI agents spent years trying to solve a mystery: whether officials from Saudi Arabia, one of Washington's closest allies, were involved in the worst terror attack in US history. This is their story.
item.kicker: SO MUCH MORE TO THE STORY

item.title: Operation Encore And The Saudi Connection: A Secret History Of The 9/11 Investigation
item.description: Behind the scenes, a small team of FBI agents spent years trying to solve a stubborn mystery — whether officials from Saudi Arabia, one of Washington's closest allies, were involved in the worst terror attack in US history. This is their story.
item.kicker: SO MUCH MORE TO THE STORY

item.title: The War Between Microsoft And The IRS
item.description: For years, the company has moved billions in profits to Puerto Rico to avoid taxes. When the IRS pushed it to pay, Microsoft protested that the agency wasn't being nice. Then it aggressively fought back in court, lobbied Congress and changed the law.

item.title: They Were Promised Broadband And High-Tech Jobs. They're Still Waiting
item.description: Kentucky's state leaders told rural residents it would create better business opportunities. But instead, they keep getting left behind.

item.title: Six Children Died In Border Patrol Care. Democrats In Congress Want To Know Why
item.description: Video obtained by ProPublica contradicted the Border Patrol's account of 16-year-old Carlos Gregorio Hernandez Vasquez's death. Now, House Democrats are pressuring the agency to explain why six migrant children died under its care in less than a year.
item.kicker: THEY DIED BETWEEN SEPTEMBER 2018 AND MAY 2019

item.title: Lawmakers Refused To Increase An Infamous Prison's Funding. Then, Chaos Erupted
item.description: Understaffed and underfunded, Mississippi's Parchman prison recently received media attention for its grisly violence, gang control and subhuman living conditions. However, lawmakers have known about these issues for years, and have done nothing to fix it.

item.title: How To Investigate Professors' Conflicts Of Interest
item.description: When professors moonlight, the income may influence their research and policy views. Here's how to get to the bottom of it all.

item.title: California's Jails Are In A Deadly Crisis. Here's How Experts Suggest Fixing Them
item.description: An investigation by McClatchy and ProPublica found unchecked violence and inhumane conditions in county jails, but the state's oversight agency has no power to stop it.

item.title: How Trump's Trade War Is Making Lobbyists Rich And Slamming Small Businesses
item.description: Washington's influence industry, including former Trump officials and allies, has made big money helping companies get exemptions from tariffs — sometimes by undercutting small business owners like Mike Elrod.

item.title: The IRS Tried To Crack Down On Rich People Using An 'Abusive' Tax Deduction. It Hasn't Gone So Well
item.description: The tax agency, Justice Department and Congress have all taken aim at a much-abused deduction exploited by wealthy investors. Yet the crackdown is having minimal impact, costing the Treasury billions.
item.kicker: THE RICH WON AGAIN? WE'RE SHOCKED

item.title: What We Found In Three Years Of Documenting Hate
item.description: As the project investigating hate in America comes to an end, we look back at reporting highlights and the impact of our work.

item.title: The Family Wanted A Do Not Resuscitate Order. The Doctors Didn't
item.description: Andy Jurtschenko told his children that he didn't want to be a burden on them. But after he suffered brain damage during a heart transplant, his medical team deflected their request for a DNR.

item.title: What Happens When Sheriffs Release Violent Offenders To Avoid Paying Their Medical Bills
item.description: Sheriffs regularly release sick and injured inmates to avoid paying their hospital bills. But some defendants charged with violent offenses like murder have been let out and gone on to commit new crimes.
